transcript.text: - Yaël Braun-Pivet: The first question
will be asked by Mr. Laurent Marcangeli,
the president of the Horizons group.
- Laurent Marcangeli: Thank you, Madam
President.
Mr. Prime Minister, "Reading
is eating and drinking.
The mind that does not read loses weight
like the body that does not eat."
I borrow these words from Victor Hugo
to alert the government
as well as our fellow citizens on a major subject:
the dizzying drop in the practice
of reading among the youngest.
It's 2024, and reading has never been more
accessible to everyone, in many formats.
To put it another way, we have never had as much
opportunity to read as we do today.
However, the results of a recent study
on the practice of reading
among young people are edifying:
20% of 7-19 year olds cannot read for
more than 15 minutes without stopping.
7-12 year olds spend, on average, 23 minutes
reading, compared to more than 2 hours on screens,
every day.
The older you get, the wider this gap
becomes.
These figures can only concern us.
Being a society means sharing a common history,
a physical heritage, but also a literary one,
a set of fundamental values.
Culture is part of it and I firmly believe
that reading is its glue.
Plus, not surprisingly,
much of that screen time has been spent
on social media.
And this, earlier and earlier
and for longer and longer.
I would like here to renew my call
to implement as quickly as possible
the law establishing a numerical majority set
at 15 years.
Mr Prime Minister, without a shared past,
there can be no common present.
Without reading, no transmission,
but a general erasure of memories.
Therefore, defending reading
means defending national cohesion.
Can you tell us how
the government plans to encourage more of
our children to read?
Thank you.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you very much.
The floor is given to the Prime Minister.
- Gabriel Attal: Thank you, Madam President.
Mr. President Laurent Marcangeli,
I know your attachment
and your mobilization on this subject
of reading, more generally
on the place of screens and social networks
in the lives of our young people.
This is a subject of great concern
for the entire national representation.
I am going to cite the work carried out
by Annie Genevard and Fabrice Le Vigoureux,
who produced a very good report,
in January, on the question
of reading.
Myself, as Minister of National Education
and Youth, I spoke of a
potential educational and health
disaster due to this predominant role
of screens among young people, and particularly
among the youngest.
I say it again here as Prime Minister,
I do not want a country where TikTok replaces
novels, where influencers replace
great authors and where screens
gradually take over all the space in the lives
of our young people, and more broadly
in that of citizens, with an obviously terrible impact
for society.
It’s an education issue,
you can’t learn well
if you don’t know how to read well.
This is a citizenship issue.
The transmission of our culture obviously passes
through its authors and the ability to read
and learn.
It is a health issue,
because more screen time means
less sleep, less sport.
For all these reasons, we do not mobilize,
first of all with the action we carry out
in primary school, a refocusing
on fundamental knowledge.
We also have daily reading
for our young people.
In these age groups,
reading time stabilizes and tends
to increase.
We must continue to move forward.
The report submitted in January
will help us do this.
At college, we were pioneers
in the previous mandate,
we banned the use of cell phones.
We were the first country to do so.
I see that many countries
around us are wondering.
The Minister of National Education
said she was ready to go
further.
Finally, there is the question of the digital majority
at 15 years old.
As Minister of Education,
I launched work with platforms
and social networks to put
in place a digital lock.
We have the possibility, by working
with the platforms, to be able to verify the age
of users who register
on social networks.
Between 13 and 15 years old, no account
on social networks without
parental authorization.
Furthermore, we have launched a health commission
on the subject, but also expert work
to better support parents
and give them more methodology and
advice for this role of screens
with their children and with young people.
The work will be handed over to us shortly.
When you're 13, you have no business being
in front of a screen at 3 a.m.
It's important to remember this.
This commission will help us.
As you can see, we share
this concern.
I believe it is widely shared.
We see the directions on which
we must act.
We are ready to go
further on all these subjects.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you very much.
The floor is given to Ms. Annick Cousin,
for the National Rally.
- Annick Cousin: Thank you.
Mr Prime Minister, the cost
of energy remains one of the major concerns
of our fellow citizens.
Thanks to the alliance of nuclear
and hydraulic production, the French could
and should benefit from one
of the cheapest electricity in Europe.
The reform of the European electricity market,
which will be voted on this evening in the European Parliament,
and which your government welcomed,
is a scam.
In this agreement, there is no questioning
of the rules for liberalizing
the energy market,
which have been a failure for more than 20 years.
The bills of households and the majority
of businesses have exploded, following
your disastrous political choices
and will not decrease.
The price of electricity will be indexed
to the marginal cost of the last unit
of production called into the market,
a barbaric term to say that bills will be submitted
to speculators and the costs of imported gas.
Unfortunately, exactly
what Marine Le Pen said
during the presidential campaign is happening .
You will not only raise
prices, but you will impose
cost slippage on invoices,
even though you promised the opposite.
This agreement exposes businesses,
French households and taxpayers
to the benefit of Germany and speculators.
It is imperative to put an end
to this absurdity and injustice.
When are you going to lower the electricity bill
by 40%, as proposed by the National Rally?
We must regain control of energy.
We need to be able
to have low-cost energy,
since we produce it ourselves.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you very much.
Mr Prime Minister?
- Gabriel Attal: Thank you, Madam President.
Madam Deputy Cousin, there is always
a form of irony in hearing
National Rally deputies give
lessons on energy matters,
and I say, hearing you...
Calm down, everything is fine.
Let me express myself.
Hearing you defend
nuclear power is not without salt:
a few years ago, Marine
Le Pen called for an end to nuclear power.
She wanted us to let go of that energy.
We are in a European
electricity market.
Was this European electricity market
perfect?
No, we've always said it.
Was it necessary to come out of it in a resounding way,
as you proposed?
The answer is no.
Exiting the European electricity market
means that you risk a blackout
at certain times.
We recently had to import
electricity.
Leaving the European electricity market
means that there are times
when you can no longer export electricity
as we do today.
But the reality is that with the National Rally,
you are proposing a Frexit in pieces,
you are proposing to leave the European
electricity market because you want to leave
the European Union.
You systematically propose to get out
of all the rules and all
the common projects
that we have in the European Union,
because you do not like Europe.
This European electricity market is
therefore not perfect.
That's why we
evolved it.
The reform which will be presented to the vote protects
nuclear power much better than the European
electricity market previously.
We have obtained, and France has obtained,
the presence of nuclear power in this
electricity market.
This reform will allow something
very clear and very simple:
that our compatriots pay for electricity
at a controlled cost, close to the cost
of producing the energy mix.
We will ensure
that it is less exposed to large
price variations.
Listening to the National Rally,
these permanent changes of footing,
this desire to exit the European
electricity market, the back and forth
on nuclear power, we say to ourselves
that you will be very satisfied with a situation
where we would be totally dependent
on the energy of the Russians and the great
international powers.
That's your hidden project
for the French.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you very much.
The floor is given to Mr. Sébastien Jumel,
for the GDR group.
- Sébastien Jumel: Mr. Prime Minister,
I tell you with a form of seriousness:
your choice to declare social war
on the entire country is irresponsible.
Minimum welfare recipients,
the unemployed and, today, civil servants
are brutalized.
Things are clear, this path
of challenge has a double objective:
divide, divide and divide
the French again, by designating
scapegoats, and this to avoid
a real debate on tax justice,
which would involve the ultra-rich,
who see their wealth disappear under your reign.
We count 10 billion
more with you, proof that this government
chooses to hit the weak hard,
but remains an ocean of gentleness
for the wealthiest.
So that the circle is closed,
after having trampled the National Assembly
with 49.3, the president dreams
of bypassing Parliament, by refusing
a vote on your austerity plan.
You acknowledge your extreme solitude
and you now dream of doing
without Parliament.
By reducing the resources of local authorities,
there will be fewer local public services.
By cutting nearly 700 million euros
from National Education,
thousands of teaching positions
and classes have been eliminated.
You also tax the sick.
However, another option is possible,
the creation of a contribution
on the highest assets.
You must give up this idea
of ​​social VAT.
She is unfair.
Pull yourself together.
Accept the democratic debate,
let everyone assume their positions
here in the hemicycle.
Be convinced that, for us, the urgency
is to sew the Republic back together
against the liberals who divide,
against the extreme right which feeds on them,
and be convinced that for us, the urgency
is to find the way back to a peaceful country.
The left will know how to come together.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you very much.
The floor is given to the Prime Minister.
- Gabriel Attal: Thank you.
Mr. Deputy Sébastien Jumel,
there were few questions
in your question.
It was above all a declamation,
you agree.
You have addressed an important issue
for us, which is obviously
that of the rearmament of our public services.
We are all attached
to our public services,
and we are lucky, in France,
to have public agents in health,
in the police, in the armies,
in justice, in education
and in many other areas. other areas,
which are alongside the French
to protect them.
What we have been keen to do
since 2017 is to rearm
our public services.
I hear the debates and the criticisms,
it is always legitimate, in a democracy,
and we are here to respond
and debate it, but give me a period
when public services were strengthened as much
as we have since. 2017.
A period where the National Education budget
has increased as much as in the last two years,
a period where the health budget
has increased as much as this last year.
We have massively strengthened and rearmed
the budget of our public services,
because it is a national treasure
and our French are happy
to be able to count on these public services.
We did it, Mr. Deputy,
without increasing taxes, by allowing
economic activity to develop
in our country.
It is because we have created 2.4 million jobs
in recent years that the employment rate
is at its highest since it was measured.
We have benefited from additional revenues
to re-arm public services.
We have not created any additional taxes or duties.
We have seen in the past that this results in
less revenue, because there is less
economic activity, and therefore fewer resources
to invest in public services.
We will not deviate from this strategy.
We will do everything to support employment
in our country.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you very much.
The floor is now given to Mr. Alain David,
for the Socialist Group.
- Alain David: Thank you.
Mr Prime Minister,
your Minister responsible for the Civil Service
yesterday launched a consultation
on civil service reform.
The eight unions representing
the public service
are not particularly calling for such a reform
, which they consider dogmatic and far removed
from the concerns of public officials.
Far from leaving any room for listening
to the unions and for real consultation,
the minister short-circuited this work
by immediately declaring in the press that he wanted to lift
the taboo on the dismissal of civil servants.
This way of doing things, already used
in the previous reform,
which the unions continue to denounce,
is nevertheless very ineffective.
What a lack of understanding of the underlying reasons
for the status of the civil service.
The job guarantee is only the fair compensation
for more modest salaries.
It makes it possible to avoid salary competition
with the private sector and to retain skills.
It also guarantees the loyalty
of public officials, prevents
temptations of corruption, the sustainability
of public service and the republican ideal.
Mr Prime Minister,
will the consultation be an opportunity for a real
negotiation on the conditions of exercise
and remuneration of
civil servants' missions?
Or is this a new charade
to further degrade public services
as you degrade our social model,
by attacking job seekers?
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you.
Mr Prime Minister?
- Gabriel Attal: Thank you, Madam President.
MP Alain David, I was
just speaking, in response to MP Jumel,
about our attachment to public service
and civil servants.
Obviously, with this objective,
we want to continue to support
our public service, to help it evolve where
it is necessary.
I had the opportunity to do this
in my general policy declaration,
before the national representation,
we want a reform
whose heart will be to better take into account
the work and merit in the advancement
of our civil servants.
I will give you two objectives:
to promote agents of proven value with
a taste for initiative and a sense
of responsibility on the one hand, and to award
a bonus to agents who have accomplished
a particular task on the other hand.
Do you agree
with these two objectives?
I don't know if you disagree
or not, but
it's not me who expresses
these two objectives, it's Maurice Thorez.
To speak of merit and support for the responsibilities
of public officials is not to insult
the public service, on the contrary.
It is recognizing the work, creativity,
talent and responsibility
of our public officials.
When I announced this upcoming reform,
I said that it would be presented
after summer.
End of summer, or beginning of fall.
This is to leave plenty of time
for consultation.
This is what was launched today
by the minister.
Consultation with trade union organizations.
I call on everyone to come
around the table, to work,
to put everything on the table,
in a constructive spirit
which is that of the government.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you.
Go ahead, Mr. Congressman.
- Alain David: Mr Prime Minister,
after your response, I only have one thing
to say to you: stop the destruction
of our social model and our republican model.
THANKS.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you.
The floor is given to Ms. Laurence Maillart-Méhaignerie,
for the Renaissance group.
- Laurence Maillart-Méhaignerie:
Mr Prime Minister, in July 2023,
a few weeks after the conclusions
of the citizens' convention on the end
of life, with several deputies of different
political sensibilities, including some of my colleagues,
we published in Le Monde
a forum, from which I would like to quote
a few extracts.
"For many years, our fellow citizens have
increasingly expressed themselves in favor of changing
the legislative framework for end-of-life support
and allowing the legalization
of active assistance in dying, within a
very precisely defined framework.
They are also asking access to
quality palliative care, everywhere and for everyone.
However, never before has our country passed
such a law of freedom for French men
and women suffering at an advanced
or terminal stage from a serious illness
and incurable, whose physical
or psychological
suffering is unbearable and unrelievable.
We, parliamentarians from different political groups
in the National Assembly, we no
longer want to turn a blind eye to this unspeakable suffering,
to these demands of our fellow citizens.
We demand a law of free choice
which would not impose anything on anyone
and which would respect all consciences.
It is time for France to finally take up
this law which is framed and respectful
of all, caregivers and patients.
Here we are.
A bill on support
for the sick and those at the end of life was presented
this morning to the Council of Ministers."
Can you present to us the broad outlines
of this bill expected
by a large majority of French people?
- Gabriel Attal: Madam Deputy
Maillart-Méhaignerie, the relationship
with death, with one's own death,
is the most intimate there is,
and the most difficult there is.
It very often refers to personal experiences.
It refers to spiritual convictions, philosophical.
It also refers
in many cases to a complex question.
It is therefore with the greatest care
and the greatest prudence that the President
of the Republic has chosen to move forward
to respond to the aspirations of patients
and keep his commitment made
during the
2022 presidential campaign
. Taking into account the work of the national consultative ethics committee and
the citizens' convention, the President
of the Republic laid out
a few weeks ago now
the contours of a new development
of end-of-life legislation
in our country.
This new framework is that of the bill
that we adopted this morning
in the Council of Ministers, and which was transmitted
in Parliament.
You will have to examine it in public session
in a few weeks, starting
May 27.
I am already specifying here
that the accelerated procedure
will not be initiated to allow
debates to take place as long
as necessary and for a consensus
to emerge.
This new model is based
on one goal, that of dignity,
dignity by always better supporting
those who suffer.
This is why, without waiting for this bill
, and it was also the agenda
of the Council of Ministers
this morning, and following the
unanimous request of caregivers, we unveiled
this week a 10-year strategy
for supportive care
with exceptional investments
which consist of an
even broader approach than palliative care.
More than a billion euros more than today
and a 10-year strategy,
so that everyone can have access
to palliative care.
Dignity also means admitting that,
despite all the commitment of our caregivers,
sometimes the illness wins.
This is why the President
of the Republic proposed creating
the possibility of resorting to active assistance
in dying.
It was a request, an expectation,
sometimes a hope from patients
and families who told us
that it was imperative to change
our law.
This is also what emerged from the citizens' convention
on the end of life, the work of which
was reported in April 2023.
Madam Deputy, this active assistance
in dying will meet very strict criteria
and the ultimate decision taken
by the doctor after consulting other
health professionals.
Patients must be adults, they must be capable of full
and complete
discernment , they must be affected
by an incurable illness, which imposes
refractory suffering,
and have their vital prognosis compromised
in the short or medium term.
These guarantees are strong,
they are necessary, they are,
in the government's sense, the condition
which allows ethics
and dignity to rhyme
. I know and I hope that the debates
in this hemicycle will be held
with the greatest respect for
everyone's convictions and, obviously, with a sense
of responsibility that we
all owe to the sick and families
who await this progress.
Thank you.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you very much.
The floor is given to Mr. Frédéric Mathieu,
for the La France Insoumise group.
- Frédéric Mathieu: Thank you.
Mr. Prime Minister, six months:
we had to wait six months
for the President of the Republic to sign
a column finally calling for an immediate and permanent ceasefire
in Gaza.
It took tens
of thousands of deaths and numerous violations
of international law for you to finally
listen to reason.
Whatever it may have cost us,
my group held this position
from day one, without giving in
to the pressure.
Moreover, last week,
we addressed this
to the President of the Republic,
to ask him to stop
all arms deliveries to Israel.
We fervently hope that the flash
of lucidity which led her to call
for a ceasefire continues.
France must go all the way
in his refusal of genocide
by not providing the means
for its realization.
Are you ready to commit here
and now, before the national representation
, to stopping all exports of
French arms to Israel?
Are you ready to call on all
countries concerned to stop their own arms deliveries
to Israel?
Thank you.
- Gabriel Attal: Thank you, Madam President.
Mr. Deputy Frédéric Mathieu,
before answering your question,
I want to remind you, and I deplore
the fact that we have to do so with each response
to questions from La France Insoumise,
that this dramatic situation
follows a despicable
and barbaric terrorist attack. committed by Hamas
on Israeli soil.
Listening to you, it would be an idea
that came up just like that, one morning,
on the part of Israel, to intervene
in Gaza.
You never say a word
about the victims of the Hamas attack.
You never talk about our hostages,
who are still being held
in Gaza today.
There are
three French hostages .
I regret having to make this reminder
each time La France Insoumise speaks
on this subject.
For the rest, Mr. Deputy,
I regret that, week after week,
month after month, while the Minister
of the Armed Forces has spoken systematically
and responded to your questions,
you continue to relay false information.
The Minister of the Armed Forces was extremely clear.
First, our exports to Israel
are very limited.
Secondly, Sébastien Lecornu
also said it, our exports
are essentially components
which are used in the Israeli defense system
to protect its soil.
It is reality.
Finally, I want to say it here too,
France was the country
which earliest called for an end
to the spiral of violence in Gaza,
through the voice of the President of the Republic.
He was criticized for this at the time.
France is the country in Europe
which has taken initiatives at the European level,
in the dialogue we have with Israel
and all the countries in the area,
but you are incapable
of recognizing that, because you do not are guided
by nothing other than your ideology
and a desire that you
constantly have to lower France
and humanity.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you.
Thank you very much, Prime Minister.
- Frédéric Mathieu: Mr. Prime Minister,
I believe that it is you who are demeaning
France and who are showing great indignity,
while you are exploiting this drama,
this catastrophe, for
internal political
reasons . We do not avenge one crime with another crime.
The genocide in Gaza
will not bring back the hostages.
The genocide in Gaza
will not bring back the victims of October 7.
Understand that, at some point.
Integrate it, at some point.
Do the honor of France, follow through
on this conviction.
A simple press release will not be enough.
What do we do?
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you.
Sir!
The floor is given to Mr. Benjamin Lucas,
for the environmental group.
- Benjamin Lucas: Mr Prime Minister,
you have received a message
from the High Council for the Climate
which alerts you to the level of emergency
on mitigating global warming
and alarms you about what was voted on.
This fascination demonstrates your abandonment
of any climatic ambition.
Not moving fast enough and far enough
is going backwards.
We are roughly the same age.
We are the first generation fully aware
of the climate peril, the first
who knows that we must take up this challenge
of ecological transformation.
You, who have more power than any other individual
of our generation in the country, will you finally act
for the climate?
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you.
Mr Prime Minister.
- Gabriel Attal: Thank you, Madam President.
Mr. Deputy Benjamin Lucas,
it's true, we are from the same
generation and there are a certain
number of us from this generation in this hemicycle,
and I am delighted about that.
I deeply believe that the fight
of our generation is indeed
that of the ecological transition
and the fight against
global warming.
I am totally convinced of it.
The question, from there, is how
to give ourselves the means to get there.
I had the opportunity to recall it
in my general policy declaration,
I believe in a popular ecology,
an ecology of solutions, an ecology of investment
rather than an ecology of punishment
and permanent brutality.
That’s good, that’s precisely
the goal of this government
and this majority.
Yes, the High Council for the Climate
wrote to me, indeed.
He called on me to apply and keep
the commitments that have been made
within the framework of ecological planning,
to meet climate ambition.
Mr. MP, when I hear you relay
this letter, and therefore worry
that our ambition in terms of ecological planning
is not being met, I see it as recognition
that our ecological planning
is ambitious, which you have never said .
You recognize a posteriori
and a little late that, yes,
we are the majority who have the most ambition
on the environmental climate issue.
In addition to being from the same generation,
I also embrace it.
We belonged to the same political family,
for a time.
It was a time when she exercised
responsibilities.
I accept it, yes.
When we compare the investment
for the environment that took place
at that time, when the environmentalists,
the Greens were in government,
and the financial investment
that there was today, there
is no comparison, but a lot more money today.
I remember that at the time, the ecological fight
was for some people limited to major projects
like Notre-Dame des Landes, the Golden Mountain,
in Guyana.
Have any of these projects been resolved?
No.
This majority is the one who solved certain
problems.
There was a lot of talk about the fight
against waste and the circular economy
at the time.
Who voted for this law?
It is this majority and this government.
The result is that before the election
of the President of the Republic,
in 2017, CO2 emissions fell,
on average, by one percent per year.
In the first five-year term of the President
of the Republic, emissions
fell on average by 2% per year.
Last year they fell
5% over the year.
It's historic.
There is no comparison possible
in the history of the country.
Not only do I fully support the policy
that is being pursued, but I am proud of it.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you.
- Benjamin Lucas: What a shame
that we cannot live
on this imaginary planet
that you are building and inventing!
Are you going to stop paying lip service
to this essential question
for this generation
and those that will follow it?
Your formulas will not be enough,
you, the youngest Prime Minister
in history, as you like
to remind us, are you going to put an end
to this old-fashioned vision of the country
which ignores that society is ready
for ecological bifurcation?
Are you going to put an end to productivist myths?
Are you going to put an end to this unhealthy passion
for fossils, whether it concerns
energies or the ideological references
that are yours?
How many forests burned, crops sacrificed,
landscapes disfigured, species decimated,
regions flooded, communities deprived of water,
families trapped
in their thermal sieve, or will it take
to take the measure of the actions
required of you?
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you.
Mr Prime Minister?
- Gabriel Attal: So, Mr.
Deputy, we can be from the same generation
and not have the same vision.
I assume.
I, Mr. Deputy, will never indulge,
as you do too regularly,
in a vision which consists of explaining
to our generation that they are condemned
to live less well than their predecessors
in order to respect the environment.
If it is the only speech
that we hear, no one will mobilize.
Rather than banning cars, I prefer
that electric battery factories open
in Dunkirk, as we have managed
to do.
Rather than banning airplanes
for everyone, I prefer
that we invest in low-carbon airplanes
and the airplane of the future.
Rather than saying that we must
be in deproduction, in decline,
close factories, I prefer to act
for an economy that respects the climate,
but which allows everyone to work
and live with dignity from their work.
Unlike you, I believe
it is possible and we are in action.
- Yaël Braun-Pivet: Thank you.
The floor is given to Madam Vice-President
Elodie Jacquier-Laforge for the Democratic group.
- Elodie Jacquier-Laforge: As you know,
the European Parliament will vote today,
at 5 p.m., on the 10 texts which form
the asylum and migration pact.
The European Union has succeeded, after several years,
in unifying around this pact,
for which we have worked hard, in particular
our MEP colleagues.
As a reminder, these texts will allow
better control of irregular immigration
at our borders, with an annual budget
of 900 million euros. A review of harmonized
and fairer
asylum procedures
, as well as the establishment of a solidarity mechanism
between our member states is also planned in order
to better manage the 960,000 asylum applications filed
This is with policies such
as this one that we can act on.
It is a social and coherent impact.
However, while some develop
an obsession around the theme of immigration,
they are not only conspicuous
by their absence from substantive debates,
but also by their political incoherence.
Indeed, when our majority deputies work
with our European partners, others feed fears.
